newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany calls Britain to "the heart of Europe".
newsitem.headline: Germany calls Britain to "the heart of Europe".

text.p: Germany wants Britain to be "at the heart of Europe" as the 15-member bloc seeks a closer union, but London must shift some of its policies to get there, Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel said on Thursday.

Kinkel, briefing parliament on last week's European Union summit in Dublin, said Germany and France -- the traditional motors of European integration -- would make a joint proposal for further reform by the next EU summit in December.
In an appeal to Britain, he then echoed the pro-European words Prime Minister John Major used during his first visit to Bonn as British leader back in 1991.
"We also want to see Britain 'at the heart of Europe' and not on its periphery," Kinkel said in a speech, adding: "But for that, a few things have to be moved forward."

Especially since the "mad cow" crisis this spring, many Germans have all but written Major's government off as a partner in Europe and openly expressed hopes that Labour leader Tony Blair will win the next British election.
For their part, Euro-sceptics in Major's ruling party portray Chancellor Helmut Kohl's enthusiastic pro-EU stand as a veiled German bid to gain dominance over the continent.

Despite attacks by Euro-sceptics, Major has tried to preserve Britain's influence in negotiations reviewing the Maastricht treaty by insisting London must have a say in how EU's planned single currency works even if it does not join.
Kinkel did not spell out where he felt Britain had to modify its policies to come more in line with its EU partners.
But his list of priorities for the inter-governmental conference deliberating a reform of the 1991 Maastricht treaty included several points London opposes.

He called for a single European currency in 1999, more majority voting in the EU, a strengthening of the European Parliament and the transformation of the Western European Union (WEU) into the EU's defence arm.
The minister hoped EU members could agree by their Dublin summit in December to cooperate more in regulating immigration and fighting the drug trade, terrorism and organised crime.
"If there is one litmus test our citizens have for Europe's ability to solve its problems, this is it," he said.

Kinkel also stressed that the so-called flexibility clause, which would let some states forge ahead towards deeper cooperation while others lag behind, must not lead to a "Europe a la carte" in which members went their own ways.
"We do not want to replace the one European Union with three or four 'special unions'," he argued. "That would be a bad trade."
The opposition Social Democrats (SPD) said Britain was not the only state blocking progress in EU integration and accused the Kohl government of slowing down necessary reforms.

Heidemarie Wieczorek-Zeul, the SPD's European affairs spokeswoman, said recent Kohl comments about putting some decisions off for a few years meant the EU would miss reforms needed before it took in new eastern European members.
"The result of this harakiri course will be that only finance ministers and their bureaucrats will have a say in the EU," she said. "The political union would have no chance."
The SPD wanted a "tax union" to harmonise tax levels and ensure that companies could not move production to countries with lower costs, leaving growing unemployment in their wake.
Kinkel saw unemployment as Europe's most pressing problem but rejected the call to put a jobs clause into the EU treaty.

"We will not create a single new job by changing the treaty," he said. "That would just distract us from the real challenge all member states must tackle themselves, namely to deregulate, cut their public spending and lower taxes."
